962.text:

Although the legislative power of the United

974.text:

have been in the years leading up to the War

1982.text:
of Independence. Consideration was given to

convention. However, the delegates decided
not to proceed in that way at that time.

One of the founders of the American republic,
Alexander Hamilton, was opposed to the idea

2000.text:
of a bill of rights. As Carol Berkin puts
it in her recent history of the drafting process:

2007.text:
"Hamilton insisted that [it] was redundant
in a Lockean republic. Guarantees of rights,

2014.text:
he declared, might be valuable as stipulations
between kings and their subjects. But in a

2022.text:
constitution 'founded upon the power of the
people, and executed by their immediate representatives

2028.text:
and servants - the people surrender nothing,
and as they retain everything they have no

Nevertheless it soon became apparent to the

2045.text:
in order to assist in the ratification process,

2051.text:
amendments to the Constitution by enacting
what became the Bill of Rights. This was what

2057.text:
James Madison then achieved and the first
10 amendments were ratified by 1791. Some

2065.text:
had a concern that setting out certain rights
expressly in a bill of rights might be taken

2071.text:
to imply that they were the only rights which
people have. That would have been contrary

2078.text:
to the natural rights theory in which they
believed as heirs to John Locke. It was for

2084.text:
this reason that the final two amendments
were included in the Bill of Rights. They

2089.text:

2095.text:
the Supreme Court. The Ninth Amendment states:
"The enumeration, in the Constitution, of

2103.text:

deny or disparage others retained by the people."

The Tenth Amendment states: "The powers not
delegated to the United States by the Constitution,

2121.text:
nor prohibited by it to the states, are reserved

2133.text:
As a major example of the way in which American
constitutional law protects fundamental rights,

2142.text:
I now intend to consider the right to freedom
of speech. This is one of the rights contained

2148.text:
in the First Amendment. That amendment has
attained an almost mythical status not only

2155.text:
in American law but in American culture. Even
the fact that it is numbered the First Amendment

2162.text:
has had some significance attached to it.
In fact, as it happens, in the original draft

2168.text:
Bill of Rights, the rights which are now contained
in the First Amendment were to have been in

2174.text:
a clause numbered four. Madison's original
proposal would have made textual amendments

2180.text:
to the main body of the Constitution. It was
only later that it was decided to set out

2186.text:
the amendments separately, in effect as an
addendum to the Constitution. Even in the

2192.text:
version which was eventually passed by both
Houses of Congress and sent to the states

2196.text:
for ratification, freedom of speech was mentioned
in the third proposed amendment. Since the

2203.text:
first was never ratified and the second had
to wait another 200 years before it was ratified

2210.text:
in 1992, the famous clause concerning freedom
of speech and religion became the First Amendment.

2218.text:
The second point to make about the express
language of the First Amendment is that, on

2223.text:
its face, it applies only to the federal government
and not to the states. In fact, if read literally,

2231.text:
it applies only to one branch even of the
federal government, namely Congress. So far

2238.text:
as relevant it provides that Congress shall
make no law abridging the freedom of speech.

2246.text:
There was in Madison's original proposal an
amendment, in the then clause 5, which would

2252.text:
have included a prohibition on violation of
"the freedom of the press" against the states

2259.text:
but this was not enacted in the final version
of the Bill of Rights.

2265.text:
The jurisprudence of the US Supreme Court
only established that the right to freedom

2269.text:
of speech applied to the states indirectly
in the early part of the 20th century. This

2276.text:
was achieved through the "due process" clause
of the Fourteenth Amendment, which prohibits

2282.text:
the states from depriving any person of life,
liberty or property without due process of

2289.text:
law. The Fourteenth Amendment was one of the
amendments passed after the American Civil

2294.text:
War in the late 1860s. To a lawyer in this
country it might seem surprising at first

2302.text:
sight that a clause which appears to deal
with "due process" has been interpreted by

2310.text:
the US Supreme Court to include substantive
guarantees as well. However, in American law

2318.text:
it is now well established that this is the
case. Americans refer to this doctrine as

2324.text:
"substantive due process." This is the vehicle
by which the Bill of Rights has been held

2329.text: to bind the states as well

2405.text:
Despite the rhetoric which surrounds the First
Amendment, and indeed the Bill of Rights more

2409.text:
generally, it took a long time for the Supreme
Court to establish the modern principles on

2415.text:
freedom of speech. As Eric Foner puts it:
"Today, the liberties enshrined in the Bill

2423.text:
of Rights are central to Americans' conception
of freedom. This has not always been the case;

2430.text:
indeed, at many moments in our history, from
the suppression of abolitionist meetings in

2435.text:
the 1830s to the Red Scare after World War
I and the depredations of McCarthyism during

2442.text:
the Cold War, individual rights have been
seriously curtailed - often in the name of

2448.text:
freedom. The growth of civil liberties in
this country is not a story of linear progress

2454.text:
or simply a series of Supreme Court decisions,
but a highly uneven and bitterly contested

2460.text: part of the story of American freedom."

2465.text:
Samuel Walker, in his history of the American
Civil Liberties Union, suggests that: "There

2471.text:
was no tradition of free speech before World
War I, in either legal doctrine or public

2477.text:
tolerance for unpopular views. The glittering
phrases of the First Amendment

2482.text:
were an empty promise to the labor movement,
immigrants, unorthodox religious sects, and

2490.text:
political radicals. Intolerance began with
the first English settlers who attempted to

2496.text:
suppress religious heresy. The Puritans may
have come to the new world seeking religious

2502.text:
freedom for themselves, but they had no intention
of granting it to others in their own communities.

2510.text:
Through the end of the nineteenth century,
American society was a set of 'island communities',

2515.text:
each a 'closed enclave', intolerant of the
ideas or behavior it disliked."

2521.text:
Indeed, Walker suggests that in the 19th century
"the courts scarcely functioned in many frontier

2528.text:
communities. The majority imposed swift and
certain justice through vigilante action."

2538.text:
There is a well-established distinction in
American constitutional law between the restriction

2542.text:
of the "content" of speech and the regulation
of the time, place, and manner of the exercise

2550.text:
of the right to freedom of speech. It is conventionally
thought that regulation of time, place and

2555.text: manner is permissible as long as it is reasonable.

2560.text:
When it comes to the content of speech, the
generally received wisdom is that Americans

2565.text:
will not tolerate any restriction of what
they can say at all. However, this has never

2572.text:
been the law. Historically the way in which
the US Supreme Court addressed the problem

2579.text:
was by recognising that there were certain
categories of speech which were outside the

2584.text:
protection of the First Amendment. Traditionally
obscenity was such a category, although in

2590.text:
practice today this will hardly apply in the
case of adults. Child pornography is an entirely

2597.text:
different matter. Another famous category
of unprotected speech relates to what Americans

2603.text:
call "fighting words." Even defamation, although
the doctrines have been different in our two

2611.text:
countries, is not protected speech under the
First Amendment. It has also long been recognised

2618.text:
in American law that the state is entitled
to criminalise incitement to commit criminal

2624.text:
acts. However, as a result of what was originally
called the "clear and present danger" test,

2630.text:
it has been established that there has to
be a close nexus between the words used and

2635.text:
the likelihood of a criminal offence in fact
occurring.

2641.text:
The problems with which both our countries
are grappling today are not new ones. A hundred

2647.text:
years ago, shortly after the First World War
and the Russian Revolution, America had to

2652.text:
address the question of what, if any, restrictions
could be placed on "extremist" speech. At

2660.text:
that time the fear was of violent revolution
along the lines of what had just happened

2668.text:
One of the most famous such cases was Whitney
v California (1927). Anita Whitney was a member

2676.text:
of the Socialist Party who was arrested after
giving a speech called "The Negro Question",

2681.text:
in which she protested about race riots and
lynching. She was convicted under a California

2687.text:
law which prohibited "criminal syndicalism."
She was convicted of assisting in organising

2695.text:
an association to advocate terrorism. Although
the US Supreme Court upheld that conviction,

2703.text:
Justice Brandeis concurred rather than dissented.
However, his concurring judgment is usually

2711.text:
regarded as being tantamount to a dissenting
one. It has also been described by his recent

2717.text:
biographer, Jeffrey Rosen, as "a kind of constitutional
poetry."

2725.text:
In Whitney Brandeis said: "Those who won our
independence believed that the final end of

2734.text:
the state was to make men free to develop
their faculties, and that in its government

2740.text:
the deliberative forces should prevail over
the arbitrary. They valued liberty both as

2748.text:
an end and as a means. They believed liberty
to be the secret of happiness and courage

2754.text:
to be the secret of liberty. They believed
that freedom to think as you will and to speak

2760.text:
as you think are means indispensable to the
discovery and spread of political truth; that

2768.text:
without free speech and assembly discussion
would be futile; that with them, discussion

2774.text:
affords ordinarily adequate protection against
the dissemination of noxious doctrine; that

2781.text:
the greatest menace to freedom is an inert
people; that public discussion is a political

2788.text:
duty; and that this should be a fundamental
principle of the American government."

2796.text:
As Rosen observes, Brandeis clearly had in
mind the words of President Jefferson in his

2802.text:
first inaugural address in 1801: "That though
the will of the majority is in all cases to

2811.text:
prevail, that will to be rightful must be
reasonable; that the minority possess their

2817.text:
equal rights, which equal law must protect,
and to violate would be oppression." Brandeis

2825.text:
echoed those words when he said that: "Recognising
the occasional tyrannies of governing majorities,

2833.text:
they [i.e. the Founders] amended the Constitution
so that free speech and assembly should be

2841.text:

from Jefferson's inaugural and said, at para.

2854.text:
In most respects, this means that the will
of the majority must prevail. But valuing

2859.text:
each person equally also means that the will
of the majority cannot prevail if it is inconsistent

2867.text:
with the equal rights of minorities." In fact,
as we have seen, Anita Whitney's conviction

2875.text:
was upheld by the Supreme Court and Brandeis'
opinion was a concurring one, even if it reads

2881.text:
like a dissent. A month after the court's
decision, the Governor of California pardoned

2887.text:
her, saying that freedom of speech is the
"indispensable birthright of every free American."

2892.text:
She was soon to be back
before the courts, for violating a state statute

which made it a crime to display a red flag.
In 1931 the US Supreme Court held that that

law was "repugnant to the guaranty of liberty

In the last 25 years the US Supreme Court
has come to recognise that there are no categories

2920.text:
of speech which are in principle unprotected
by the First Amendment. On the other hand,

2925.text:
the Court has also come to recognise that
it may be possible in principle for the state

2930.text:
to regulate even the content of speech where
a law is narrowly tailored to serve a compelling

2936.text:
state interest. This is sometimes called "strict
scrutiny." In this way, although Americans

2943.text:
would not necessarily use the same terminology
as we use in Europe, there is in practice

2949.text:
a doctrine similar to our own principle of
proportionality. Accordingly, I would suggest

2955.text:
that, although at first sight the experiences
of the US and the UK appear to be very different

2961.text:
in the context of freedom of expression, in
fact there are many similarities too. A major

2967.text:

democratic societies, including the United
Kingdom: see its decision in RAV v City of

United Kingdom has not had, until relatively

3006.text:

values underlying it were embedded in the

3013.text:
culture of this country and in the common
law for many centuries. In particular the

3019.text:
marketplace of ideas theory can be found in
the writings of John Stuart Mill in the 19th

3026.text:
century. They were clearly influential on
the jurisprudence of the US Supreme Court

3032.text:
in the early part of the 20th century, e.g.
Abrams v United States (1919).

3041.text:
More recently, it is clear that the flow of
ideas has also come in the other direction:

3047.text:
American law has influenced our law, even
before the Human Rights Act came into force.

3054.text:
Most notable was the decision of the House
of Lords in R v Secretary of State for the

Home Department, ex parte Simms (1999). Lord

3068.text:
course, intrinsically important: it is valued

that it is also instrumentally important.
It serves a number of broad objectives. First,

3081.text:
it promotes the self-fulfilment of individuals
in society. Secondly, in the famous words

3088.text:
of Holmes J (echoing John Stuart Mill), 'the

to get itself accepted in the competition

250 US 616, 630 per Holmes J (dissenting).
Thirdly, freedom of speech is the lifeblood

3106.text:
of democracy. The free flow of information
and ideas informs political debate. It is

3112.text:
a safety valve: people are more ready to accept
decisions that go against them if they can

3119.text:
in principle seek to influence them. It acts
as a brake on the abuse of power by public

3125.text:
officials. It facilitates the exposure of
errors in the government and administration

Another example of American "constitutional

case: West Virginia State Board of Education

there is any fixed star in our constitutional

matters of opinion, or force citizens to confess

Note even the use of alliteration in that

thought to be one of the most fundamental

3199.text:
Court held that Jehovah's witnesses could

3207.text:
that the decision, which reversed the court's

what Americans thought they were fighting

As the Divisional Court (of which I was a
member) said, after citing these authorities,

"History has taught us that, in fields as

diverse as politics, religion, science and

3252.text:
Furthermore, as the European Court of Human
Rights has often said in its jurisprudence

3257.text:
on Article 10, freedom of expression constitutes
one of the essential foundations of a democratic

society. Accordingly "it is applicable not

3272.text:
received or regarded as inoffensive or as
a matter of indifference, but also to those

3279.text:
that offend, shock or disturb the state or

The jurisprudence of the European Court has
frequently stressed that the hallmarks of

3291.text:
a democratic society are not simply that the
will of the majority must prevail. Rather

3298.text:
a democratic society is characterised by pluralism,
tolerance and broad-mindedness. In this context

3308.text:
I would recall again what was said by the

3314.text:
49: "these words, which appear in many of

The framers of the Convention, arising as

in the 1930's and 1940's, recognised that

necessary will be acceptable in a democratic

3350.text:
As I said at the outset of this lecture, both
the United States and the United Kingdom have

3354.text:
mature legal systems, with a strong tradition
of judicial independence and respect for the

3361.text:
rule of law. In this context, judicial independence
is a particular aspect of the separation of

3369.text:
It is often thought that in the US judges
are elected. In fact the picture is much more

3377.text:
complicated. There is an important distinction
between the federal judiciary and judges in

3384.text:
each of the states. It is in the nature of
American federalism that there will be different

3390.text:
systems for the appointment of judges in each
state.

3394.text:
The federal judiciary are not elected at all.
The Constitution created the Supreme Court,

3401.text:
although its composition was not spelt out
in the Constitution itself and has been affected

3407.text:
by Congressional legislation since 1789. Over
time the number of judges on the Supreme Court

3414.text:
has been increased to its current number of
nine, including the Chief Justice. The power

3422.text:
to appoint judges to the Supreme Court is
vested by the Constitution in the President,

3428.text:
with the "advice and consent" of the Senate.
A similar appointment process is used for

3436.text:
the District Bench and the US Court of Appeals,
which is divided into various circuits, covering

3442.text:
the vast geographical area of the United States'
territory.

3448.text:
Presidential appointments, in particular to
the Supreme Court, can be the subject of intense

3453.text:
public debate. There are confirmation hearings
before the US Senate. Some see this as an

3461.text:
unfortunate introduction of partisanship into
what should be an independent process; others

3469.text:
regard it as an important, democratic check
on what is otherwise the great power vested

3475.text:
in the Supreme Court. Although judicial interpretations
of the Constitution can be reversed by constitutional

3483.text:
amendment, the system for amendment of the
Constitution was deliberately made difficult

3488.text:
by the Founders, and in practice, it is rare
for a decision of the US Supreme Court to

3494.text:
be overturned in this manner. That means that
the prospect of having well-established judicial

3500.text:
decisions of that court overturned can be
the subject of intense political controversy:

3507.text:
in particular the decision of the US Supreme
Court in Roe v Wade (1973), which decided

3516.text:
that the Constitution confers the right to
choose to have an abortion.

3522.text:
Since February last year there has been a
vacancy on the US Supreme Court, arising from

3526.text:
the death of Justice Scalia. President Obama
nominated Merrick Garland for the appointment

3534.text:
but the Senate declined to consider the nomination
before the outcome of the Presidential election

3540.text:
was known in November. At the end of January
this year the new President, Donald Trump,

3548.text:
nominated another judge to fill the same vacancy:
Neil Gorsuch. It will now be for the US Senate

3555.text: to decide whether to confirm that appointment.

3560.text:
So far as state courts are concerned, the
practice relating to judicial appointments

3565.text:
varies enormously. Originally each of the
13 states after the War of Independence selected

3572.text:
its judges through either executive or legislative
appointment. There were at that time no elections

3581.text:
for the state judiciary. However, in the first
half of the 19th century there was a democratic

3587.text:
movement associated with the presidency of
Andrew Jackson, often referred to as "Jacksonian

3594.text:
democracy." As it has been put by Rachel Paine
Caufield: "states began to move away from

3602.text:
appointive selection methods in the mid-eighteen
hundreds with the rise of Jacksonian democracy

3609.text:
and its emphasis on democratic accountability,
individual equality, and direct voter participation

3616.text:
in governmental decision-making." By the time
of the American Civil War the vast majority

3623.text:
of states had changed their method of judicial
selection to direct election by the voters.

3629.text:
However, a contrary trend began to emerge
in the first half of the 20th century. This

3636.text:
was initially associated with the Progressive
era. A movement began for what Americans call

3643.text:
a "merit system." The first state to adopt
the merit system was Missouri in 1940. Since

3651.text:
then a large number of states have adopted
such a system, in particular for the highest

3656.text:
court in each state. In fact 24 of the states
and the District of Columbia have adopted

3663.text:
some form of merit system, "making it the
most prevalent system of judicial selection

3669.text:
in use in the United States today." As Brian
Fitzpatrick explains, although there are differences

3676.text:
among these various systems, they have two
common features. First, with regard to initial

3683.text:
selection, judges are not elected but are
appointed by the Governor of the state, from

3689.text:
a list of names submitted by a nominating
commission. Secondly, at some point after

3695.text:
appointment in most of the systems, state
judges must come before the public in a referendum

3701.text:
(albeit an uncontested one), through which
voters can remove a judge from the bench.

3709.text:
Even in those states where there is no election
for the initial appointment of a state judge,

3713.text:
and for this purpose I will confine myself
to the highest court in the state, the general

3719.text:
practice tends to be that a judge must then
face a "retention" election. I will describe

3727.text:
the practice in the state with which I am
most familiar, that is California. According

3733.text:
to the constitution of the State of California,
judges for the Supreme Court must be nominated

3738.text:
by the Governor and confirmed by the Commission
on Judicial Appointments, which consists of

3744.text:
the Chief Justice, the Attorney General, and
the Presiding Justice of the Court of Appeals.

Since 1979 it has been required that the State

3757.text:
should conduct a thorough investigation of
the background and qualifications of prospective

3762.text:
nominees. However, the Governor is not bound
by that commission's recommendations. Once

3769.text:
appointed, judges must stand for retention
at the time of the next gubernatorial election

3775.text:
after their appointment. Appellate judges
serve twelve year terms. Although, in many

3782.text:
states, judicial retention elections are low
key affairs, in the state of California they

3788.text:
have often been controversial. I remember
that, while I was a student in California

3793.text:
in 1986, there was a well organised campaign
against some members of the state Supreme

3799.text:
Court, including the Chief Justice, Rose Elizabeth
Bird. The particular reason why they were

3807.text:
unpopular with many electors was their perceived
antipathy to use of the death penalty. A total

3814.text:
of $11.5 million was spent on campaigning
both for and against the judges, setting what

3821.text:
was at that time a record for spending in
a judicial election. They were voted off the

3830.text:
In this country, of course, we have no election
for judges, not even what the Americans call

3835.text:
a "retention" election. There was a time,
around the turn of the 19th and 20th centuries,

3843.text:
when Lord Halsbury was Lord Chancellor in
the Salisbury governments, when party affiliation

3848.text:
does appear to have played a part in judicial
appointments. However, that has long since

3855.text:
passed. In any event, today we have the Judicial
Appointments Commission (in England and Wales).

3863.text:
That commission was created by Parliament
in the Constitutional Reform Act 2005, with

3869.text:
the express purpose of placing it at arm's
length from the government of the day. There

3874.text:
are similar appointment bodies in Scotland
and Northern Ireland. When it comes to the

3880.text:
Supreme Court of the UK, appointees are selected
by a panel which includes representatives

3887.text:
of the JAC and its counterparts in the other
parts of the UK. The sole criterion for judicial

3896.text:
appointments is merit: that is now a statutory
requirement in the 2005 Act.

In the past it was not uncommon for judges
in this country to have had party political

3910.text:
careers. Some of our best judges had such
a background:36 for example, Lord Reid, who

3929.text:
served with great distinction on our highest
court, the House of Lords, between 1949 and

1975, had been a Conservative MP. Another

straight to become President of the old Probate,

3954.text:
Harold Macmillan's government. There was until
well into the 20th century a practice by which,

3961.text:
if the post of Lord Chief Justice became vacant,
the Attorney General of the day had the right

3968.text:
Sir Rufus Isaacs became Lord Reading CJ in
that way, having been a Liberal MP and a member

3974.text:
of the Asquith Government. Indeed our modern
sensibilities about the separation of powers

3979.text:
may be quite recent. While Lord Reading was
a serving Chief Justice, he was also appointed

3986.text:
to be this country's ambassador to the United
States. The last such appointment was that

3993.text:
of Lord Hewart CJ, who had been a Conservative
MP and Attorney General in the National government

4001.text:
In the United States, one former President
became Chief Justice of the US Supreme Court

4007.text:
(William Howard Taft). One of the most successful
Chief Justices in American history, Earl Warren,

4013.text:
had been a Republican Governor of California
and only just lost out to Eisenhower for the

4018.text:
Republican nomination for the presidency in
1952. It is often reported that, when President

4024.text:
Eisenhower left the White House, he was asked
whether he had made any mistakes during his

4029.text:
presidency. He replied "only two: and they
are both sitting on the Supreme Court." He

4036.text:
was thinking of Chief Justice Warren and Justice
Brennan.

4040.text:
There can be no doubt that some great American
judges have previously held high political

4046.text:
office. For example Justice Robert Jackson
had been Attorney General in the administration

4051.text:
of President Franklin Roosevelt and served
with great distinction both on the US Supreme

4056.text:
Court and as the Chief Prosecutor at the Nueremberg
War Crimes Tribunal after the Second World

4063.text:
War. More recently, one of the current justices
of the Supreme Court, Elena Kegan, was Solicitor

4070.text:
General in President Obama's administration,
having previously been Dean of Harvard law

4077.text:
In this country also we have experience of
such appointments, indeed quite recently.

4082.text:
Lord Mackay of Clashfern was a highly regarded
Lord Chancellor and Law Lord, having previously

4088.text:
been Lord Advocate in Margaret Thatcher's
government. More recently still, Lord Rodger

4092.text:
of Earlsferry was a highly regarded Law Lord
and then Justice of the Supreme Court, having

4098.text:
previously been Lord Advocate in the John
Major administration. Indeed some commentators

4103.text:
would suggest that it can be desirable for
the senior judiciary to include at least some

4109.text:
judges who have previous experience of government
and the legislature, in the light of the important

4115.text:
constitutional questions which judges sometimes
have to decide. This does not compromise the

4122.text:
principle of independence, provided there
is a separation of powers at the time when

4128.text:
they are serving judges. Judges must relinquish
any links they may have had with a political

4136.text: party on their appointment to the bench.

4142.text:
I would like to end with a few concluding
remarks. Clearly the United States and the

4149.text:
United Kingdom have a long and shared commitment
to constitutionalism. However, the structural

4156.text:
differences between the two constitutional
systems mean that it is difficult to prune

4162.text:
principles from one legal system and simply
transplant them to the very different soil

4169.text:
of the other. Sometimes we use the same phrases,
such as "separation of powers" and "due process"

4178.text:
but these can be false friends, as their meaning
may be quite different in the two countries.

4185.text:
Having said that, the two systems have clearly
influenced each other too and continue to

4191.text:
do so, as in the field of freedom of speech.
Looking at the jurisprudence of the US can

4199.text:
be helpful in providing useful insights into
the way in which a problem is analysed, even

4207.text:
if the answer would not necessarily be the
same. It can also, quite simply, be enjoyable

4216.text:
for the "constitutional poetry" one can find
there.
